lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and correctly use “like” in positive and negative sentences and Yes/No questions.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) On the board, sort examples: “I like cats.” / “I don’t like frogs.” / “Do you like turtles?” Students sort into columns.
stretchStrategies: Like Ladder: On the board, draw a 4-step “ladder.” Model a sentence: “I like cats.” Students must take turns making new sentences that build on the last (e.g. “I like cats and frogs.” → “I don’t like cats, but I like turtles.”). Encourage longer compound sentences and creativity.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and identify the initial sounds (r, l, o).
supportStrategies: (Phonics) Say /r/, /l/, /o/. Students repeat, then circle those sounds in a list of simple words in the SB.

Encourage longer compound sentences and creativity.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can complete short sentence frames (e.g., I ____ ____) using the correct form of “like”.
supportStrategies: (Writing) Show sentence frame: “I like ___.” or “I don’t like ___.” Students write 1–2 sentences using animal words.

items: Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.
Bạn muốn ăn gì? >> you want to eat what? [what do you want to eat?]
This is extremely difficult to master, especially combined with do-support.

Phonics introduces each vowel with one sound, which quickly breaks down past the Kindergarten 2 level. Think of the es in elephant or the as in banana. This does not happen in Vietnamese, where every vowel is pronounced as written.
Bạn có thích ăn bánh mì không? >> you like eat bread? [do you like to eat bánh mì?]
